item.title: RealSense spins out of Intel to scale its stereoscopic imaging technology
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Szkutak
item.description: RealSense is building vision tech that helps machines like robots and drones navigate and respond to a 3D world.

item.title: Grok 4 seems to consult Elon Musk to answer controversial questions
item.dc:creator: Maxwell Zeff
item.description: This raises real questions around how "maximally truth-seeking" Grok is designed to be, versus how much it's designed to just agree with Musk, the world's richest man.

item.title: Tesla is already trying to expand its robotaxi service to Arizona
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Korosec, Sean O'Kane
item.description: Tesla has applied for a permit to test and deploy autonomous vehicles in Arizona. It's also eyeing expansion in Austin, Texas, and California.

item.title: AWS is launching an AI agent marketplace next week with Anthropic as a partner
item.dc:creator: Jagmeet Singh
item.description: Amazon Web Services is launching an AI agent marketplace and Anthropic is one of its partners.

item.title: Where AI meets design: Runway co-founder Alejandro Matamala Ortiz takes the AI Stage at TechCrunch Disrupt 2025
item.dc:creator: TechCrunch Events
item.description: TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 is the epicenter where 10,000+ startup and VC leaders gather to explore the future of innovation — and this year, two AI Stages bring the intersection of design and machine learning into sharp focus. We’re thrilled to welcome Alejandro Matamala Ortiz, co-founder and chief design officer at Runway, to one of the […]

item.title: How to actually raise a seed round: Actionable advice from top investors at TechCrunch Disrupt 2025
item.dc:creator: TechCrunch Events
item.description: This isn’t your typical venture panel. Expect sharp insights on how to cut through the noise, structure your raise, and build relationships that last beyond a term sheet. Whether you're gearing up for your first round or advising a founder who is, this is the TC Disrupt session you don’t want to miss.

item.title: Former Intel CEO launches a benchmark to measure AI alignment
item.dc:creator: Maxwell Zeff
item.description: Former Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger created a new benchmark to test for AI model's alignment with aspects of human flourishing.

item.title: Belkin ends support for most Wemo devices and its Wemo app
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description: Another day, another smart device bites the dust -- or, in this case, a full lineup of smart devices. On Thursday, Belkin announced it will end technical support for its older Wemo products as of January 31, 2026, and the app used to control the devices will no longer be supported. The decision will impact a range of devices, including smart plugs, light switches, smart bulbs, baby monitors, kitchen appliances, heaters, air purifiers, motion sensors, and more.

item.title: Mockly made a fake DM generator that’s actually user-friendly
item.dc:creator: Amanda Silberling
item.description: Tools like Mockly have existed since the dawn of instant messaging, but they generally aren't the most user-friendly apps. Mockly manages to set itself apart while iterating on such a popular idea by simply being usable.

item.title: With Varda Space, leading Silicon Valley players make big bet on making drugs in space
item.dc:creator: Aria Alamalhodaei
item.description: Varda Space has been fueled with new capital to scale its in-space drug manufacturing business.

item.title: 5 days until TechCrunch All Stage — save up to $475 before prices rise
item.dc:creator: TechCrunch Events
item.description: In just five days, startup leaders from across the country will descend on Boston’s SoWa Power Station for TechCrunch All Stage 2025 — and your chance to lock in the lowest ticket prices will be gone.

item.title: They took away Linda Yaccarino’s blue check!
item.dc:creator: Amanda Silberling
item.description: Before she stepped down, Yaccarino had a blue check next to her display name, accompanied by an X logo, signifying that she is affiliated with the company that brought us Mecha Hitler. Now both badges are gone.

item.title: YouTube is getting rid of its Trending page and Trending Now list
item.dc:creator: Aisha Malik
item.description: YouTube is replacing these Trending lists with category-specific charts, the company announced on Thursday.

item.title: As X loses its CEO, daily usage is down and competition is growing
item.dc:creator: Sarah Perez
item.description: X is still the dominant social media platform, but its daily active user base has declined and competitor Threads is seeing higher rates of growth.

item.title: Nvidia reportedly plans to release new AI chip designed for China
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Szkutak
item.description: Nvidia plans to release a chip that is retrofitted from an existing Blackwell processor that was modified to meet chip export rules.

item.title: French police arrest Russian basketball player accused of ransomware: Report
item.dc:creator: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
item.description: Daniil Kasatkin was reportedly arrested in a Paris airport on June 21 at the request of U.S. authorities.

item.title: Slate Auto: Everything you need to know about the Bezos-backed EV startup
item.dc:creator: Sean O'Kane
item.description: Slate auto burst onto the scene in April 2025. Here is a timeline that covers its origins, backers, product, and other new details.

item.title: Google adds image-to-video generation capability to Veo 3
item.dc:creator: Ivan Mehta
item.description: Google said on Thursday it's adding an image-to-video generation feature to its Veo 3 AI video generator through its Gemini app.

item.title: Authorities arrest four hackers linked to UK retail hacking spree
item.dc:creator: Zack Whittaker
item.description: The U.K. National Crime Agency said the suspects are in custody in relation to the hacks targeting Marks & Spencer, Harrods, and the Co-op.

item.title: Grok is coming to Tesla vehicles ‘next week,’ says Elon Musk
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Bellan
item.description: Elon Musk said in a post on X early Thursday morning that Grok – the chatbot from his AI company, xAI – will be coming to Tesla vehicles “very soon.” “Next week at the latest,” he said.
